speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: SCENE I. A hall in DUKE SOLINUS'S palace.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, AEGEON, Gaoler, Officers, and other Attendants

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And by the doom of death end woes and all.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: I am not partial to infringe our laws:

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: The enmity and discord which of late

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To merchants, our well-dealing countrymen,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Who wanting guilders to redeem their lives

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their bloods,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Excludes all pity from our threatening looks.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: For, since the mortal and intestine jars

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: It hath in solemn synods been decreed

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Both by the Syracusians and ourselves,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To admit no traffic to our adverse towns Nay, more,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: If any born at Ephesus be seen

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: At any Syracusian marts and fairs;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Again: if any Syracusian born

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Come to the bay of Ephesus, he dies,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: His goods confiscate to the duke's dispose,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Unless a thousand marks be levied,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To quit the penalty and to ransom him.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Thy substance, valued at the highest rate,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Cannot amount unto a hundred marks;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Yet this my comfort: when your words are done,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: My woes end likewise with the evening sun.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Why thou departed'st from thy native home

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A heavier task could not have been imposed

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Yet, that the world may witness that my end

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: I'll utter what my sorrows give me leave.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: In Syracusa was I born, and wed

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Unto a woman, happy but for me,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And by me, had not our hap been bad.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: With her I lived in joy; our wealth increased

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: By prosperous voyages I often made

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: To Epidamnum; till my factor's death

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And the great care of goods at random left

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: From whom my absence was not six months old

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Before herself, almost at fainting under

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: The pleasing punishment that women bear,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Had made provision for her following me

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And soon and safe arrived where I was.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: There had she not been long, but she became

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A joyful mother of two goodly sons;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And, which was strange, the one so like the other,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: As could not be distinguish'd but by names.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: That very hour, and in the self-same inn,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A meaner woman was delivered

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Of such a burden, male twins, both alike:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Those,--for their parents were exceeding poor,--

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: I bought and brought up to attend my sons.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Made daily motions for our home return:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Unwilling I agreed. Alas! too soon,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: We came aboard.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Before the always wind-obeying deep

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Gave any tragic instance of our harm:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: But longer did we not retain much hope;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: For what obscured light the heavens did grant

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Did but convey unto our fearful minds

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: A doubtful warrant of immediate death;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Which though myself would gladly have embraced,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Yet the incessant weepings of my wife,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Weeping before for what she saw must come,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And piteous plainings of the pretty babes,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: That mourn'd for fashion, ignorant what to fear,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Forced me to seek delays for them and me.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And this it was, for other means was none:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: The sailors sought for safety by our boat,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: My wife, more careful for the latter-born,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Had fasten'd him unto a small spare mast,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Such as seafaring men provide for storms;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: To him one of the other twins was bound,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Whilst I had been like heedful of the other:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: The children thus disposed, my wife and I,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Fasten'd ourselves at either end the mast;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And floating straight, obedient to the stream,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: At length the sun, gazing upon the earth,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Dispersed those vapours that offended us;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And by the benefit of his wished light,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: The seas wax'd calm, and we discovered

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Two ships from far making amain to us,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: But ere they came,--O, let me say no more!

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Gather the sequel by that went before.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Nay, forward, old man; do not break off so;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: For we may pity, though not pardon thee.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: O, had the gods done so, I had not now

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Worthily term'd them merciless to us!

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: We were encounterd by a mighty rock;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Which being violently borne upon,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: So that, in this unjust divorce of us,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Fortune had left to both of us alike

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: What to delight in, what to sorrow for.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Her part, poor soul! seeming as burdened

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: With lesser weight but not with lesser woe,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Was carried with more speed before the wind;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And in our sight they three were taken up

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: At length, another ship had seized on us;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And, knowing whom it was their hap to save,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Gave healthful welcome to their shipwreck'd guests;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And would have reft the fishers of their prey,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Had not their bark been very slow of sail;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And therefore homeward did they bend their course.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Thus have you heard me sever'd from my bliss;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Do me the favour to dilate at full

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: What hath befall'n of them and thee till now.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: At eighteen years became inquisitive

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: After his brother: and importuned me

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: That his attendant--so his case was like,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name--

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Might bear him company in the quest of him:

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Whom whilst I labour'd of a love to see,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: I hazarded the loss of whom I loved.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Five summers have I spent in furthest Greece,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Or that or any place that harbours men.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: But here must end the story of my life;

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: And happy were I in my timely death,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Could all my travels warrant me they live.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Hapless AEgeon, whom the fates have mark'd

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To bear the extremity of dire mishap!

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Now, trust me, were it not against our laws,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Against my crown, my oath, my dignity,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Which princes, would they, may not disannul,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: My soul would sue as advocate for thee.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: But, though thou art adjudged to the death

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: And passed sentence may not be recall'd

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: But to our honour's great disparagement,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Yet I will favour thee in what I can.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Therefore, merchant, I'll limit thee this day

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: To seek thy life by beneficial help:

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus;

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Beg thou, or borrow, to make up the sum,

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: And live; if no, then thou art doom'd to die.

speaker: DUKE SOLINUS
text_entry: Gaoler, take him to thy custody.

speaker: Gaoler
text_entry: I will, my lord.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Hopeless and helpless doth AEgeon wend,

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: But to procrastinate his lifeless end.

speaker: AEGEON
text_entry: Exeunt
